pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
Thanks. It doesn't segfault anymore, but it still doesn't start recording.

If I do this:

`$ gz log -d 1`

It records to a timestamped directory in `~/.gazebo/log/`

I expected to choose an output file like this:

`$ gz log -d 1 -o ~/testlog2.log`

But it doesn't record anything and gives me this error:

`No source log file specified. Use the -f command line argument.`
content.html:
Thanks. It doesn't segfault anymore, but it still doesn't start recording.

If I do this:

$ gz log -d 1

It records to a timestamped directory in ~/.gazebo/log/

I expected to choose an output file like this:

$ gz log -d 1 -o ~/testlog2.log

But it doesn't record anything and gives me this error:

No source log file specified. Use the -f command line argument.

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw: To filter an existing log file. Let's say you have a 50GB log file, and you only want to have pose information, then you can do `gz log -f source.log -o dest.log --filter *.pose`
content.html: To filter an existing log file. Let's say you have a 50GB log file, and you only want to have pose information, then you can do gz log -f source.log -o dest.log --filter *.pose

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
I just notice that if I run `make UNIT_gz_log_TEST` it does not compile the `gz` utility and we are using it in the test. What about declaring the dependency?

```
#!patch
diff -r 0d1b68956eca tools/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/tools/CMakeLists.txt	Tue Feb 23 21:12:14 2016 +0100
+++ b/tools/CMakeLists.txt	Wed Feb 24 20:30:42 2016 +0100
@@ -37,7 +37,9 @@
 
 gz_build_tests(${test_sources})
 
-add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+if (ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION)
+  add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+endif()
 
 add_executable(gz gz.cc gz_topic.cc gz_log.cc)
 target_link_libraries(gz
```
content.html:
I just notice that if I run make UNIT_gz_log_TEST it does not compile the gz utility and we are using it in the test. What about declaring the dependency?

diff -r 0d1b68956eca tools/CMakeLists.txt
--- a/tools/CMakeLists.txt  Tue Feb 23 21:12:14 2016 +0100
+++ b/tools/CMakeLists.txt  Wed Feb 24 20:30:42 2016 +0100
@@ -37,7 +37,9 @@

 gz_build_tests(${test_sources})

-add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+if (ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION)
+  add_dependencies(${TEST_TYPE}_gz_log_TEST gz)
+endif()

 add_executable(gz gz.cc gz_topic.cc gz_log.cc)
 target_link_libraries(gz

content.html:
could we get rid of the i extra variable by doing something like:

diff -r 0d1b68956eca tools/gz_log.cc
--- a/tools/gz_log.cc   Tue Feb 23 07:13:40 2016 -0800
+++ b/tools/gz_log.cc   Tue Feb 23 20:19:44 2016 +0100
@@ -837,17 +837,18 @@
     outFile.write(header.c_str(), header.size());
   }

-
   StateFilter filter(!_raw, _stamp, _hz);
   filter.Init(_filter);

-  unsigned int i = 0;
+  if (_raw)
+  {
+    play->Step(stateString)
+    stateString.clear();
+  }
+
   while (play->Step(stateString))
   {
-    if (i > 0)
-      stateString = filter.Filter(stateString);
-    else if (i == 0 && _raw)
-      stateString.clear();
+    stateString = filter.Filter(stateString);

     if (!stateString.empty())
     {
@@ -898,8 +899,6 @@
         outFile.write(stateString.c_str(), stateString.size());
       }
     }
-
-    ++i;
   }

   if (!_raw)

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
Run the `gz log` twice, on the original, and the first output file return different log files. I'm not sure if this is the expected behavior. 

```
jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f state.log -o /tmp/first.log
Warning [parser.cc:536] XML Attribute[version] in element[sdf] not defined in SDF, ignoring.
Error [parser.cc:550] Required attribute[world_name] in element[sdf] is not specified in SDF.
Warning [parser.cc:451] Unable to parse sdf element[state]
Error [parser.cc:362] parse as sdf version 1.6 failed, should try to parse as old deprecated format
jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f /tmp/first.log -o /tmp/second.log
jrivero@nium gzserver $ diff -u /tmp/first.log /tmp/second.log
--- /tmp/first.log	2016-02-24 21:25:09.321992089 +0100
+++ /tmp/second.log	2016-02-24 21:25:22.898244021 +0100
@@ -8,9 +8,6 @@
 <log_end>19 53000000</log_end>
 </header>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>
-<![CDATA[]]>
-</chunk>
-<chunk encoding='zlib'>
 <![CDATA[]]>
 </chunk>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>
```
content.html:
Run the gz log twice, on the original, and the first output file return different log files. I'm not sure if this is the expected behavior. 

jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f state.log -o /tmp/first.log
Warning [parser.cc:536] XML Attribute[version] in element[sdf] not defined in SDF, ignoring.
Error [parser.cc:550] Required attribute[world_name] in element[sdf] is not specified in SDF.
Warning [parser.cc:451] Unable to parse sdf element[state]
Error [parser.cc:362] parse as sdf version 1.6 failed, should try to parse as old deprecated format
jrivero@nium gzserver $ gz log -f /tmp/first.log -o /tmp/second.log
jrivero@nium gzserver $ diff -u /tmp/first.log /tmp/second.log
--- /tmp/first.log  2016-02-24 21:25:09.321992089 +0100
+++ /tmp/second.log 2016-02-24 21:25:22.898244021 +0100
@@ -8,9 +8,6 @@
 <log_end>19 53000000</log_end>
 </header>
 <chunk encoding='zlib'>
-<![CDATA[]]>

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw: There is no guarantee that they will be exactly the same, character for character. This is both expected, and fine. For example, a log file generated by gazebo will have a slightly different header, one that is missing a `<log_start>` and `<log_end>` tag.  The conents of the CDATA should be the same, so you could try to do a diff on just the CDATA.
content.html: There is no guarantee that they will be exactly the same, character for character. This is both expected, and fine. For example, a log file generated by gazebo will have a slightly different header, one that is missing a <log_start> and <log_end> tag. The conents of the CDATA should be the same, so you could try to do a diff on just the CDATA.

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw: Thanks for explanation. Reading the diff that I posted looks to me that the filtered version of the file lacks the first of the CDATA block contained in the original.
content.html: Thanks for explanation. Reading the diff that I posted looks to me that the filtered version of the file lacks the first of the CDATA block contained in the original.

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw: Comparing raw CDATA is not an accurate way to check if the log files are the same. The CDATA can contain multiple states, and the current log filtering will put one state in each chunk. The test included in this pull request checks exactly the situation you were manually testing.
content.html: Comparing raw CDATA is not an accurate way to check if the log files are the same. The CDATA can contain multiple states, and the current log filtering will put one state in each chunk. The test included in this pull request checks exactly the situation you were manually testing.

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw: I modified this pull request to group more states together into a frame, but it's still not a gurantee that the encoded CDATA string will be exactly the same.
content.html: I modified this pull request to group more states together into a frame, but it's still not a gurantee that the encoded CDATA string will be exactly the same.

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
If you have gazebo installed in the system, this gz command probably will use it instead of the compiled one.

I've [coded a non-portable](7bfd7bc) form of including the full path in the call, branch `gz_log_filter_output_jrivero_gzpath`
content.html:
If you have gazebo installed in the system, this gz command probably will use it instead of the compiled one.

I've coded a non-portable form of including the full path in the call, branch gz_log_filter_output_jrivero_gzpath

pullrequest.title: Allow `gz log` to output to a file

content.raw:
I found a minor problem related with man pages. If I'm not wrong, our cmake does not trigger the generation of `gz.1.gz` containing the updated version of the man page when we modify `gz.1.roff`. 

I had to remove my `build/tools/gz.1.gz` to trigger the generation and then, I could see the updated man page after running `make install`.

I believe it's fixed with [this change](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/gz_log_filter_output_caguero%0Dgz_log_filter_output#diff).
content.html:
I found a minor problem related with man pages. If I'm not wrong, our cmake does not trigger the generation of gz.1.gz containing the updated version of the man page when we modify gz.1.roff.

I had to remove my build/tools/gz.1.gz to trigger the generation and then, I could see the updated man page after running make install.

I believe it's fixed with this change.
